ji ltar snying po med pa'i chu shing la snying po 'bras bu smin la chu shing nyams pas yang dag par 'byung ba de bzhin du sangs rgyas nyid kyang ngo zhes pa'o || 'o na sangs rgyas nyid ni sgrub par byed pa byang chub sems dpa'i byang chub kyi sems su 'dod na de kho na nyid kyi sgrub par byed pa ni de kho na nyid do zhes pa'i gsungs gi phyir de yang sgyu ma las skyes pa nyid kyi phyir sgyu ma ni rang rig pa yin la
de 'jug bzhin pa'i de kho na nyid ma yin pa ji ltar sangs rgyas nyid kyi sgrub par byed par 'gyur bar 'os zhe na
gsungs pa

sdig pa zhes pa la sogs pa'o || sdig pa ni shu ka'i srin bu'o || ku li ra ni karka ta'o || gang gi skabs las 'byung ba rang gi ma de de rnams kyis nyams par byed pa ji lta ba bzhin zhes pa de ltar rnal 'byor gyis sems te
rnal 'byor ni shes rab dang thabs snyoms par 'jug pa'o || de la yod pa'i sems gang yin pa dbang bskur ba bzhi pa'i sgyu ma gang rig pa 'pho ba'i chos can gyi skabs las kun rdzob tu skyes pa yin zhing

de rnam par nyams par byed par 'gyur ro zhes pa'o || sgyu ma dang bral bas na 'khor ba slar Idog pa med par brjod de de kho na nyid kyi rnal 'byor pa rnams kyi dbugs dbyung ba'i don du'o || 'o na byang chub kyi sems ni bems po'i khams su 'dir brjod la
de yang bems po ma yin pa mchog tu mi 'gyur ba'i ye shes sangs rgyas nyid kyis sgrub par byed par ci ltar brjod ce na
brjod pa bden te

khu ba mi 'gyur ba'i rang bzhin gyis | | mchog tu mi 'gyur ba bsgom par bya'o | [sic] zhes pa'i gsung las so || de nyid kyi phyir mal 'byor gyi sems 'di'i mchog tu mi 'gyur ba'i ngo bos bzhi'i rab tu dbye ba bcu drug gsungs pa
gnyis med ces pa la sogs pa'o || gnyis zhes bya ba ni 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa'i sems te

gang la yod pa ma yin pa de gnyis med do || nor bu dang padma las g.yo ba med do zhes pa g.yo ba med do || gnyis rtogs te shes rab dang thabs kyi cha 'di la yod pa ma yin no zhes pa gnyis rtog med do || bla na med pa'i bde ba ster ba nyid kyi phyir 'dod pa'o zhes pa rnal 'byor bzhi pa'o || dbugs brgya phrag lhag pa'i stong phrag nyi shu rtsa gcig 'gog pa'i phyir mchog tu mi 'gyur ba'o || chags pa dang bral ba'i phyogs dkar po dang nag po zhes bya ba bdag gis gnas pa dang 'gro ba med pa'i phyir 'dod chags chen po'o || rnam pa dang bcas pa dang mam pa med pha las nges par grol ba nyid kyi phyir dngos dang dngos po med pa'o || shes bya ma lus pa mthong ba'i phyir ye shes so zhes rnal 'byor gsum pa'o || 'gro ba dga' bar byed pa sngon ma can sems can gyi dang po dang
dbus dang tha mar dgeg byed ba nyid kyi phyir kun tu bzang po zhes pa'o || bdud dang nyon mongs pa dang
rnam par rtog pa dang bral ba'i phyir smra ste
grag pa phyi dang nang gi brjod pa 'am

yang na rab tu sgrogs shing rnam par lhong ba'i seng ge'i sgra can gyi g.yul 'di yod pa ma yin pas sgra 'thab med pa'o || gzhom du med pa'i sgra'i ngo bo nyid kyi phyir 'di'i || sgra ste grags pa chen pa'o || zhes pa rnal 'byor gnyis pa'o 'jig rten gyi spyod pa mam par spangs pa nyid kyi phyir lhan skyes sosku bzhi'i sgrib pa zad pa'i phyir dpal Idan byang chub sems kyi thig le 'dzin pa'o || stong pa nyid dang snying rje dag dbyer med pa nyid kyi phyir dpal ldan dus kyi 'khor la rdo rje'o || tshul khrims kyi tshogs yang dag par rdzogs pa nyid kyi phyir shes rab thabs kyi bdag nyid rnal 'byor ro zhes pa mal 'byor dang po'o || da ni bla ma bsten pa'i ched du rdo rje slob dpon yongs su brtag pa gsungs padang por zhes pa la sogs pa'o || 'dir sngags kyi tshul la 'jig rten pa dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dngos grub 'dod pa'i slob ma rnams kyis bla ma la brten par bya ste de yang yang dag par yongs su brtag par bya'o zhes gsungs pa

byang chub kyi sems bsrung ba'i phyir dam tshig can no || bsten par bya ste bu dang chung ma la sogs pa rnams kyis mnyes par bya'o | | rdo rje theg par lhag par gnas pa ni sngags kyi theg pa chen po lhag par gnas pa'o || mchog tu mi 'gyur ba'i ye shes sgom pa po nyid kyi phyir de kho na nyid bsgom pa'o || bu dang chung ma la sogs pa thams cad dang rang gi lus la yang ltos pa med pa'i phyir ma chags pa'o || 'dod chags la sogs pa'i skyon dang bral ba'i phyir dri ma med pa'o || bzod pa yang tshul te 'bras bu ba ltos pa med par 'jug pa gang gi rang bzhin yin pa de ni bzod pa'i ngang tshul can no || lam ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi lam ste

de la 'jug pa'i ngang tshul can ni lam la 'jug pa'o || bla ma 'di mnyes par byas par gyur na slob ma rnams la lam gyi sbyin byed dmyal ba'i 'jigs pa 'phrog par 'gyur ro || de yang de kho na nyid las tshangs spyod ldan te mchog tu mi 'gyur ba'i bde ba thob pa'o || bdud rnams kyi ni ste bdud bzhi po rnams kyi rdo rje dbyug pa dang 'dra bas rdo rje dbyug pa ste

'joms par byed pa nyid kyi phyir ro | | brjod pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi dpal Idan bla ma ste yang rdo rje 'dzin ma'i bzhi Inga rdo rje sems dpas gyis brlabs pa'i sku can nyid kyi phyir rdo rje sems dpar rab tu grags te sprul pa'i sku yis so || da ni 'jig rten pa dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dngos grub kyi ched du lha'i dmigs pa gsungs pa
mngon sum zhes pa'o || de kho na nyid sbyor las te sna tshogs gzugs brnyan bsgom pa'i rnal 'byor pas so || skar ma'i tshogs bzhin zhes pa nor bu sngon po dang
zla ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi rnam pa can gyi thig le'i dbus sangs rgyas longs spyod rdzogs pa'i
sku mtha' yas ba mthong ba sngon ma can khams gsum pa bum pa dang snam bu la sogs pa mthong ba'o
sha'i mig gis ni dpag tshad brgya yi par du chod pa'i dngos po mthong bas te | mngon par shes pa rdzu 'phrul la sogs pa rnams kyis so
lha mig ste 'jig rten gyi khams mtha' yas pas par du chod pa'i phra mo dang cig shos kyi gzugs mthong bas so

shes rab kyi spyan gyis te chos thams cad la rnam par mi rtog pa'i mtshan nyid can gyis so
ye shes spyan gyis te dngos po thams cad kyi rnam pa thams cad mthong bas so
sems can gzhan rnams ni tshu rol mthong ba rnams so
shi ba'i lus bzhin zhes pa ni g.yo ba dang 'gul ba med pa'i phyir ro
byas pa ni sa la sogs pas so
zlum pa ni ra gan la sogs pas so
bshang ba la sogs pa ni bi ra shu mā mu ste Inga'o
go ku la sogs pa ni go ku da ha na ste Inga'o
nang du bdud rtsi Inga ni phung po Inga rnams so

gsungs pa yang | nyin dang mtshan mor thig le las ni dkar po'i rgyun 'bab gang te mā ma ki chang ma yin
go ku sogs na nyin zhag so sor mig la sogs pa spro ba'o sha gzhan res' yang ni min
rang rigs gnas pa'i lha rnams kyis ni dag pa'i lus la bdud rtsi Inga rnams bsnyan pa ste

zhes gsal byed sum cu'i bdag nyid ka tsa ta pa sa rnams nam mkha' dang rlung dang me dang chu dang sa dang ye shes kyi khams kyi rang bzhin mnams kyis dang airu yig dbyangs thung du lnga yis phye ba rnams kyis dang | de bzhin du sa la sogs pa'i rang bzhin Ị yig la sogs pa dbyangs ring po Inga yis phye ba rnams kyis te spro ba dang sdud pa'i rim pas so

original: Here, that single moment of bodhicitta, which takes place by virtue of
imperishable pleasure, is called pacified.
Here, during the great realization, the innate yoga of knowledge occurs.
unification of the mind with the unchanging pleasure occurs.
The fourth limb is the great realization
The mudrā is similar to Māyā and appears in the mind and in the ether like a figure in a mirror.
Spreading manifold rays as lightning or fire do, she illuminates the three worlds.
external from the bodies, she is devoid of sensorial objects, consists only of light, and lives in the ether.
She is made of mind: though she is one, she embraces the mind of the manifold world [LKC IV, ].
She is only an apparition of one's own mind; she is born in one's own mind, she is like an image in a mirror.
She, who was honoured by the Buddhas the sons of all the Victors, has to be honoured by the great yogins yogindra.
She, intensified by the flame of knowledge, burns all of Māra's armies along with their objects and also attachment, and so on.
Within one year, she confers the equal pleasure samasukha on the yogins' body [LKC V, ].
GBh: “By virtue of concupiscence for wisdom' means by virtue of the caṇḍālī's non-conceptual flame.
bindu, having reached the secret parts, is restrained; the speech-bindu, having reached the navel, is restrained; the body-bindu, having reached the heart, is restrained.
The knowledge- bindu is restrained 'by virtue of the imperishable pleasure', namely, by virtue of the group of bindus that have reached the top of the vajra not falling down.
[This is] the 'yoga of knowledge.
On this theme, cf. VP, comm. on LKC V, (ed., vol. III, p. ).
GBh: The mudra', viz., the great mudrā, 'is similar to Māyā', i.e., is similar to an image reflected in a clean mirror.
She ‘appears in the mind and in the ether', that is, in a mind that is non-mind acittacitta; and precisely for this reason it has been said that she is 'like a figure in a mirror' [...].
'She is not separate from external reality from the bodies' of Māyā, or in other words, she is fused with objects and sensorial faculties.
she is separate from these objects and sensorial faculties: 'she is devoid of sensorial objects', which are reflections of dharmas.
'She is one' and yet ‘embraces the mind of the manifold world.'
Therefore 'she is made of mind', i.e., she has the nature of a mind that is non-mind.
In the VP (ed., vol. III, p. , line ) Puṇḍarīka does not comment on this verse and simply writes vṛttam subodham.
GBh: The divine mudrā 'is only an apparition', a reflection, ‘of one's own mind' in which its two aspects: perceivable and perceiver are perfectly fused.
'She' is only an Wisdom and knowledge are the mind.
A tenfold image belongs to it.
The initiation is immersion into this mind, the sheen nibhā of the immaculate vimala moon, which is similar to an image reflected in a mirror.
From this originates the imperishable pleasure of nirvāṇa, which is innate, unchanging, the fourth.
The glorious master is he who, in his heart and mouth, possesses this Buddha's face [LKC V, ].
Here, wisdom and knowledge correspond respectively to the perceiver- mind and to the perceivable mind.

knowledge, i.e., the perceivable mind, is the tenfold image beginning with smoke, which can be seen as a magical image, a reflection in the mirror of what is perceivable and which belongs to it namely, to wisdom, the perceiver-mind.
This image is precisely knowledge, the perceivable mind.

In a similar way, our eye perceives itself in a mirror, appearance 'born', that is, arisen, ‘in one's own mind', which is endowed with all aspects and at the same time devoid of all aspects sarvākāranirākārarūpa.
She is ‘intensified by the flame of knowledge', i.e., by the candāli's flame [...].
'Māra's armies', which are united with 'their objects', viz., the aggregates, the elements and the bases, are the web jāla; Tib., dra ba of conceptual constructions.

It has been said: Māra is one's own mind; no other Māra exists [the full verse is quoted in AK, ed., p. ; cf. also VP, ed., vol. I, p. : māro nāma sattvānāṁ saṃsāracittam vāsanāmalaḥ, buddhatvam nāma saṃsāravāsanārahitam cittam].
analyzed: it has said māra is one s own mind no other māra exists the full verse is māraḥ nāma sattvānām saṃsāra cittam vāsanā amalaḥ buddhatvam nāma saṃsāra vāsanā rahitam cittam

original: 'She confers the equal pleasure', the pleasure of the innate bliss sahajānanda, 'within one year', viz., within Kālacakra's year, which lasts three years and three fortnights.

Or, if we accept the reading °upame instead of °upamā, which seems to be more consistent with the context, the sentence can be translated in the following way: “The initiation is immersion into this mind, which is similar to an image reflected in a mirror, bright as the immaculate moon.
From this immersion originates ....
This reading seems to be followed also by the Tibetan translation see also Gnoli-Orofino : , note .
The editors of the VP suggest the reading upamam immersion, which is similar…..”), which is possible as well.
Their conjecture does not fit in the ṢY on the basis of the GBh.
Raviśrījñāna apparently accepts the gloss by Punḍarīka according to which majjana ('immersion') would entail the first four yoga limbs.
Moreover, he considers the word vimala (‘immaculate') - which is the first word of the compound ending with upama – as an implicit reference to anusmrti.
-- like a reflected image.
The initiation is immersion into this mind.

Here in the sixfold yoga, the entrance of the perceiver-mind into this perceivable mind entrance that corresponds to withdrawal - i.e., inactivity towards external objects -, contemplation, restraint of the breath and retention is called “immersion.
From this immersion originates the imperishable pleasure of nirvāṇa, which is innate, unchanging, and the fourth pleasure.
The meaning is that this pleasure is superior to the vibrations called child and adult.
